sentences.sentence: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was King of Benares, the Bodhisatta was born as son of his chief queen.

analysis.explanation: The sentence establishes the historical and geographical context of the story, setting the stage by introducing the time period and location where the Bodhisatta's birth occurs.

sentences.sentence: On his name-day they asked 800 Brahmans, having satisfied them with all their desires, about his lucky marks.

analysis.explanation: The sentence establishes the context of the Bodhisatta's early life and the royal court's interest in his destiny, setting the stage for the Brahmans' prophecy in the subsequent sentence.

sentences.sentence: The Brahmans who had skill in divining from such marks beheld the excellence of his, and made answer: "Full of goodness, great King, is your son, and when you die he will become king; he shall be famous and renowned for his skill with the five weapons, and shall be the chief man in all India."

analysis.explanation: The sentence provides background context about the Brahmans' assessment of the prince's future, setting up the narrative for his role as the Prince of the Five Weapons. No specific location is mentioned in the sentence itself.

sentences.sentence: On hearing what the Brahmans had to say, they gave him the name of the Prince of the Five Weapons, sword, spear, bow, battle-axe, and shield.
When he came to years of discretion, and had attained the measure of sixteen years, the King said to him: "My son, go and complete your education."

analysis.explanation: The sentence represents a task assigned by the King to the Prince, instructing him to complete his education. The task role is the Prince, who is required to fulfill this responsibility.

sentences.sentence: "Who shall be my teacher?"the lad asked.

analysis.explanation: The Prince is asking about his teacher, which is part of fulfilling the King's task to complete his education.

sentences.sentence: "Go, my son; in the kingdom of Candahar, in the city of Takkasila, is a far-famed teacher from whom I wish you to learn. Take this, and give it him for a fee."

analysis.explanation: The sentence instructs the lad to seek a teacher in Takkasila and gives him money as a fee, establishing a clear task for him to complete.

sentences.sentence: With that he gave him a thousand pieces of money, and dismissed him.

analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the King giving money to the Prince and dismissing him, which is an active action performed by the King (doer) and received by the Prince (receiver).

sentences.sentence: The lad departed, and was educated by this teacher; he received the Five Weapons from him as a gift, bade him farewell, and leaving Takkasila, he began his journey to Benares, armed with the Five Weapons.

analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the lad's actions of departing, being educated, receiving the Five Weapons, and beginning his journey to Benares. The doers are the lad, and the receivers include the teacher (who gave the weapons) and Benares (the destination of his journey).

sentences.sentence: On his way he came to a forest inhabited by the Demon with the Matted Hair.

analysis.explanation: The sentence establishes the setting for the upcoming encounter with the Demon, providing context for the narrative progression.

sentences.sentence: At the entering in of the forest some men saw him, and cried out: "Hullo, young sir, keep clear of that wood! There's a Demon in it called he of the Matted Hair: he kills every man he sees!" And they tried to stop him. But the Bodhisatta, having confidence in himself, went straight on, fearless as a maned lion. When he reached mid-forest the Demon showed himself. He made himself as tall as a palm tree; his head was the size of a pagoda, his eyes as big as saucers, and he had two tusks all over knobs and bulbs; he had the face of a hawk, a variegated belly, and blue hands and feet. "Where are you going?" he shouted. "Stop! You'll make a meal for me!"

analysis.explanation: The sentence establishes the context of the Bodhisatta entering a dangerous forest inhabited by a Demon, setting the stage for the subsequent confrontation.

sentences.sentence: Said the Bodhisatta: "Demon, I came here trusting in myself. I advise you to be careful how you come near me. Here's a poisoned arrow, which I'll shoot at you and knock you down!"

analysis.explanation: The Bodhisatta initiates a confrontation by declaring his intent to attack the Demon with a poisoned arrow, which directly leads to the subsequent action of shooting the arrow. The doer is the Bodhisatta, and the receiver is the Demon.

sentences.sentence: With this menace, he fitted to his bow an arrow dipped in deadly poison, and let fly.

analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the Bodhisatta's action of preparing and launching a poisoned arrow at the Demon, making him the doer and the Demon the receiver.

sentences.sentence: The arrow stuck fast in the Demon's hair. Then he shot and shot, till he had shot away fifty arrows; and they all stuck in the Demon's hair.

analysis.changed_state: The arrows stuck in the Demon's hair, causing the Demon to snap them off and approach the Bodhisatta
analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the outcome of the Bodhisatta's prior action (shooting the poisoned arrow), resulting in the arrows becoming lodged in the Demon's hair. This leads to the Demon's reaction and the subsequent confrontation, marking a state change in the interaction.

sentences.sentence: The Demon snapped them all off short, and threw them down at his feet; then came up to the Bodhisatta, who drew his sword and struck the Demon, threatening him the while.

analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the Demon's actions of snapping and throwing arrows, followed by the Bodhisatta's action of striking the Demon, which are active events in the narrative.

sentences.sentence: His sword—it was three-and-thirty inches long—stuck in the Demon's hair! The Bodhisatta struck him with his spear—that stuck too! He struck him with his club—and that stuck too! When the Bodhisatta saw that this had stuck fast, he addressed the Demon. "You, Demon!"said he, "did you never hear of me before—the Prince of the Five Weapons? When I came into the forest which you live in I did not trust to my bow and other weapons. This day will I pound you and grind you to powder!"

analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the Bodhisatta actively using his weapons (sword, spear, club) against the Demon, with the Demon as the receiver of these actions. The sequence of striking and the declaration of resolve are active actions performed by the Bodhisatta.

sentences.sentence: Thus did he declare his resolve, and with a shout he hit at the Demon with his right hand. It stuck fast in his hair! He hit him with his left hand—that stuck too! With his right foot he kicked him—that stuck too; then with his left—and that stuck too! Then he butted at him with his head, crying, "I'll pound you to powder!" and his head stuck fast like the rest. Thus the Bodhisatta was five times snared, caught fast in five places, hanging suspended: yet he felt no fear—was not even nervous. Thought the Demon to himself: "Here's a lion of a man!  A noble man! More than man is he! Here he is, caught by a Demon like me; yet he will not fear a bit. Since I have ravaged this road, I never saw such a man. Now, why is it that he does not fear?"

analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the Bodhisatta's active actions of attacking the Demon with various weapons and body parts, which are performed by the Bodhisatta and directed at the Demon.

sentences.sentence: He was powerless to eat the man, but asked him: "Why is it, young sir, that you are not frightened to death?"

analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the Demon actively engaging in dialogue by asking the Bodhisatta a question, which constitutes an action performed by the Demon towards the Bodhisatta.

sentences.sentence: "Why should I fear, Demon?"replied he. "In one life a man can die but once. Besides, in my belly is a thunderbolt; if you eat me, you will never be able to digest it; this will tear your inwards into little bits, and kill you: so we shall both perish. That is why I fear nothing."

analysis.explanation: The Bodhisatta's dialogue constitutes an action where he uses speech to convince the Demon, with the Demon as the receiver of his words.

sentences.sentence: (By this, the Bodhisatta meant the weapon of knowledge which he had within him.) When he heard this, the Demon thought: "This young man speaks the truth. A piece of the flesh of such a lion-man as he would be too much for me to digest, if it were no bigger than a kidney-bean. I'll let him go!" So, being frightened to death, he let go the Bodhisatta, saying: "Young sir, you are a lion of a man! I will not eat you up. I set you free from my hands, as the moon is disgorged from the jaws of Rāhu after the eclipse. Go back to the company of your friends and relations!" And the Bodhisatta said: "Demon, I will go, as you say. You were born a Demon, cruel, blood-bibbing, devourer of the flesh and gore of others, because you did wickedly in former lives. If you still go on doing wickedly, you will go from darkness to darkness. But now that you have seen me you will find it impossible to do wickedly. Taking the life of living creatures causes birth, as an animal, in the world of Petas, or in the body of an Asura, or, if one is reborn as a man, it makes his life short." With this and the like monition he told him the disadvantage of the five kinds of wickedness, and the profit of the five kinds of virtue, and frightened the Demon in various ways, discoursing to him until he subdued him and made him self-denying, and established him in the five kinds of virtue; he made him worship the deity to whom offerings were made in that wood; and having carefully admonished him, departed out of it. At the entrance of the forest he told all to the people thereabout; and went on to Benares, armed with his five weapons. Afterwards he became king, and ruled righteously; and after giving alms and doing good he passed away according to his deeds.

analysis.changed_state: The Demon is subdued, becomes self-denying, and is established in the five kinds of virtue; the Bodhisatta leaves the forest, becomes king, rules righteously, and passes away according to his deeds.
analysis.explanation: The sentence describes the outcome of the Bodhisatta's prior explanation about the 'thunderbolt' (weapon of knowledge), leading to the Demon's conversion, the Bodhisatta's continued journey, and his eventual righteous reign. This represents a state change triggered by the prior interaction.
